Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: The phone in my cubicle buzzed with urgency as the sales manager’s voice echoed through the office, reminding us that today was the last chance to meet our quarterly target. My fingers hovered over the call list, heart pounding, knowing every sale counted. If I didn’t close at least three more deals, not only would my bonus vanish, but the whole team would suffer penalties. Yet, as I prepared my pitch, my phone vibrated again—this time, a message from Brother Yusuf, a devoted member of my congregation. He pleaded for a meeting, his words heavy with distress about his family. As an imam, I knew my duty was to offer him comfort and guidance, especially when he was most vulnerable. But the clock was ticking, and my manager’s expectations pressed down on me. I stared at the two phones, feeling the weight of both worlds. My mind raced, torn between the urgent demands of my job and the sacred trust of my community. The pressure built inside me, a storm of guilt and responsibility, as I tried to decide which call to answer first.
